column10: b"b' support using my own ssh key'"
b'b\' currently it seems sparkleshare generates a new ssh keypair.however
column11: i already have an ssh keypair
column12: and my personal server (as well as my github account) already allow my public key.  you should make "create new ssh keypair" optional
column13: so users like me can just toggle it off when doing for the first time.\''

column10: b'b" Right now we\'re using a new ssh-agent for SparkleShare due to various issues that turned up trying to use the existing agent and keys. Ideally
column11: the user doesn\'t have to have any knowledge of the keys existing
column12: and we\'ll have an invitation based system that handles the keys. For now
column13: we copy the public key to somewhere where the user can easily reach it. Is there a problem with using the generated key pair other than convenience?"'

column10: b"b' it needlessly overcomplicates things  makes things insecure. if you have a private encrypted key
column11: which has an unlocked version running in an existing agent (and the public key is accepted on remote servers on which i want to put sparkleshare git repositories)
column12: then
column13: if sparkleshare does not want to support this
column14: it can only do two things
column15: both are not good. 1) create a new keypair
column16: not encrypted.this means you need to configure all remote servers with sparkleshare repositories to accept the public key.this is dangerous
column17: if the client system gets compromised
column18: the private key can be obtained and abused to connect to the servers 2) create an encrypted keypair.first disadvantage of previous approach remains.this means you need to ask the user for a password (twice) when creating the keypair
column19: and every time you start sparkleshare to unlock the key in the agent.  this is pointless and extra work if there already is an unlocked key in the users agent'"

column10: b"b' Found a possible solution here: url '"

b'b" This is fixed in 949e2ed46412243d9e181214c8a8266eeb7fe37c and happens because the streamreader is using the wrong encoding. Unfortunately due to a bug in mono url  setting the right encoding doesn\'t work at the moment. So the fix will only appear when that new mono version is released."'

column10: b'b" Doesn\'t allow Gitolite Repositories"'
b'b\' Gitolite (a git authentication system) repositories take the format "ssh://**:**my-repo name" rather than "ssh://**/**my-repo name" The GUI automatically prepends the folder name with a slash
column11: which makes adding a gitolite repository impossible. I don\\\'t mind if the workaround is non-GUI
column12: but I cannot seem to find a workaround period. Seriously looking forward to using this. Hope you can take a look at it soon.\''

column10: b"b' I was trying to figure out how to use gitolite on a non-standard port since the colon is being used to reference the repo and I think this thread might have the solution to the problem here: url  as a side note gitolite+gitweb seems like a good authentication+web interface for sparkleshare'"
b'b" Great call Igordon. Guess I should\'ve tested more extensively before raising the warning flag! And here I forked for nothing..."'
b'b\' So what was the solution in the end? Did you leave out the ":"?\''
b"b' Turns out that if you use an explicit SSH url to reference the git repo
column11: you can use slash notation just like a normal repo! '"

column11: just asking because if you did some kind of workaround it\'s better to fix it in sparkles. Good that it works. :)"'

column10: b'b\' A little more info on this; gitolite does NOT appear to allow explicit ssh:// protocol connections ie on the commandline: This works:git clone username@server: This does not:git clone ssh://username@ I think the latter does authenticate with SSH but gitolite does not make the correct connection to the appropriate "virtual gitolite user"
column11: thus failing gitolite\\\'s repository permissions system. At the end of the day I got this working by: \\xe2\\x80\\x94 manually checking out my repo from the terminal into my sparkleshare folder using the syntax gitolite likes: git clone username@server: \\xe2\\x80\\x94 hand-modified the  file
column12: adding the following: I also tried the following instead of the above
column13: which also seems to work fine: Ultimately my conclusion is that it would be ideal if sparkleshare could allow a more flexible entry of the server details
column14: at the very least not presuming ssh:// as it appears to at present and perhaps ideally not mandating the / between the server and the repository name. ps thanks for the awesome work on sparkleshare... loving it :)\''

column10: b'b\' @wimh
column11: thanks for this; you have an ssh:// syntax above that I haven\\\'t tried previously
column12: and it works for me with Sparkle! Since Sparkleshare presumes ssh:// in the url (check the ~/ file to see this) my experience would suggest that the only syntax to add a gitolite repo to Sparkleshare is: ssh://user@ ...where repo is your gitolite repo with or without the .git on the end Thus the values you\\\'d put into Sparkleshare "Add remote folder..." would be:Address:// user@serverFoldername: reponame (with or without .git on the end) Seems simple stated this way but I was mislead due to other threads I read while working this out that seemed to state you need the full server path to the repo if you are using the ssh:// protocol. This appears not to be the case. I had been confused as I presumed others had a simpler server directory structure (my gitolite server is on a shared host
column13: thus is under /) Thanks all who added to this thread and helped me get this working!\''

b"b' IRC channel name bug'"

b"b' it looks like clients connect to an IRC channel (for sync notifications) that is derived from the hostname (IP?) of the git server. this is a bug. imagine the following scenario: my git server has two ethernet interfaces
column11: eth0 and eth1. eth0 has ip 23.34.23.45 and eth1 has ip 192.169.0.4. my sparkleshare client A connects to my server via eth0 using the ip 23.34.23.45 and my sparkleshare client B connects to my server via eth1 using the IP 192.169.0.4. both are configured correctly and are properly connected to the server
column12: however client A and client B end up in different IRC channels and sync messages fail to be passed properly
column13: breaking sync functionality. i experience this bug in my current setup. a solution to this is to derive the IRC channel name from something that can not change across sparkleshare clients. maybe like the hash of the initial git commit to the database or something.  the centralized irc notification system is messy. ideally it would be replaced with a lightweight custom notification center that users could optionally run on their own servers.'"

column10: b'b" Good point. Using the starting hash sounds like a good idea. I\'d like to replace the notification system. Read more about it here: url  Maybe you would like to contribute? :)"'
b'b" I need to check whether the first commit hash will most of the time be unique. I\'m not sure what git uses to compute the hash for a commit yet."'

b'b" i think there\'s a way in git to leave notes on the repository (see man git-notes). that functionality could be used to pass info between sparkleshare clients for any number of purposes. the first sparkleshare client that connects to a repo could leave a hash of the current time as a note. that could be used to generate the channel name. later clients that connect to the repo could read the note so they know which channel to join to."'
b'b" The problem with a note is: repositories that were created before SparkleShare was around won\'t work. So first commit hash might be better."'
b'b" ah hmm. i didn\'t read your reply carefully enough. yes that could work."'
b'b" Fixed in 8829c2145e868d166235You\'ll need to update all clients for it to work."'

b"b' Hang on large directory import'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: I\\\'m experimenting with sparkleshare using my own hosted git repo
column12: using Ubuntu clients:10.04
column13: compiled from current git HEAD11.04 stable 0.2 release All works fine so far in simple tests. Getting more adventurous
column14: I rsync\\\'d an entire directory structure worth of stuff into the sparkleshare folder it\\\'s about a 4Gb directory with a mix of small to very large files (100Mb plus). The sparkleshare console went nuts as it discovered all the files
column15: but things seems to be going ok. But
column16: it stopped after completing the git \\\'add\\\' operation
column17: but never went ahead to a commit.  I\\\'m not in the office any more but will post a log tomorrow. A "git status" in the directory shows a bunch of staged (added) files
column18: but no matter how long I wait
column19: the sparkleshare daemon doesn\\\'t go ahead with a commit. I stopped it
column20: did some git cleanup
column21: then restarted: $ sparkleshare stop$ cd $ git reset hard HEAD$ git clean -f -d$ sparkleshare start and it\\\'s fine again
column22: for onesy-twosy file adds.  But
column23: if I repeat the same experiment
column24: it fails in the same way again. Related to this is another pseudo-bug if sparkleshare dies after the git add
column26: it doesn\\\'t seem to detect that case when next it starts.  so
column27: you get left with a bunch of staged but uncommitted files. I could write a script to tricklefeed into the sparkleshare directory
column29: and it seems that a big initial dump like this is probably a pretty common thing for initial setups? Any suggestions on how to debug this (other than giving logs as I will do tomorrow)? Thanks for a great app
column30: given the epic authentication fail on DropBox yesterday I would expect to see a flood of users coming your way! Thanks

column10: b'b\' Strange... I\\\'d like to try with your script

column11: chmod +x\'d it and worked fine. It\'s a -ge (greater than or equal)
column12: not -eg
column13: maybe a transcription error?"'

column10: b'b" I\'ve tested on two machines
column11: one linux and one mac

column10: b'b" hmm
column11: ok i didn\'t see it actually requires arguments :)"'

column10: b"b' ok so perhaps some basic arg checking in my script would have been more friendly :)'"
b"b' Now it works and I can reproduce the problem. Still not sure what is going on though...'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: I have the same problem.For me one of the problems depends on Git. If I try "git push" for my files it tries to put everything in memory
column12: which of course fails if commit size From what I\\\'ve read Git is not built for versioning large files or handling large repositories. And the problems seem to have been in Git for a while (some threads describing the problem goes back to 2009).\''

column10: b'b" On Tue
column11: Jul 5
column13: rasmushaglund <reply@>wrote:This is a good observation a simple solution might be for sparkleshare toimplement some kind of throttling or batching of updates into multipletransactions. Or
column14: just don\'t use the git backend for large
column15: binary folders! John"'

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: maybe binary files should not automatically be versioned with Git
column12: but instead transferred with scp. There\'s really no sense in versioning a 2gb movie for example
column13: but on the other hand maybe some one want to be able to keep different versions of pictures so that the original is always backed up. Maybe the best way is to add support for syncing with  and when a user creates a new synced folder  could choose the type of the folder (). Maybe that\'s a good enough solution
column14: but I\'m not sure that the average user would be able to understand why they can\'t mix big binary files with small versioned files."'

column10: b'b" Why don\'t use the Unison backend from lgordon for big files (eq. media Just my few cents. Thomas"'
b'b\' Maybe there could be a conf-file where you could specify what kind of files to version (.txt
column11: .doc
column12: .java) and what kind of files not to (.avi
column13: .jpeg
column14: .iso). The technical solution is kind of trivial
column15: but I think the hard thing to do is making it simple enough for it to just "work".\''

column10: b"b' A conf file or preference page is not an option. This needs to be dealt with in the backend smartly. Actually git handles big files not too badly
column11: but the working memoery issue is indede a problem.'"

column10: b"b' Yeah
column11: and the real problem is big files in combination with many files in a big repository.'"

column10: b'b" I was thinking a simple solution that would require minimal rewriting of the backend could be to create a .unison folder inside the git repo and tell git to ignore that folder
column11: inside that folder use unison to sync the contents
column12: all the big files actually go in there. To make this transparent to the user just have a quick few lines of code that look for  files and move them to the .unison directory and then place a symlink back in the main git part of the repo where the file originally was
column13: you\'d have to traverse sub-folders. This is kinda like git annex but should be easy to write. Not sure how this would work on windows (symlinks?) but I think it could work well on *.  Git also seems to be quite CPU intensive on the client and server with large files."'

column10: b"b' duplicate of #290'"

b'b" @lgordon Your suggestion seams quite complex for a file sync. A think the easiest way to solve this issue is to use a different backend that better suit you\'re need. Git for many small files. Unison for many big files. Then it\'s up to the user to choose the right backend according it\'s need. General question here. Does Mercurial handle huge repository better than git ? If I get back to the original problem
column11: is it fixed in the trunk ? \'cause using the release 0.2.4 also have issue when importing large amount of small files. Thanks"'

column10: b"b'  we make a custom backend it needs to be smart and handle both cases well
column11: instead of making the user choose.'"

column10: b'b" It\'s not yet fixed in master. I\'m a bit clueless to what the problem may be..."'
b'b" From the log
column11: I understand there is something watching the local directory for any modification that occur : add
column12: remove and modification to the files. When that happen
column13: SparkleShare it launching a git command line (git status porcelaine). If that the case
column14: the issue is most probably related to the number of sub-process created by SparkleShare. It\'s creating more then 1000 process within a millisec in my case. Since the system as a limited number of process that can be created simultaneously
column15: SparkleShare reach this limit and then fail to create any other process resulting in displaying this : *\\\\* (SparkleShare:29911): WARNING **: CreateProcess: error creating process handle Notice
column16: my problem is related to adding to many files at once. I may give you further information if I manage to get your code working in Mono Develop. It\'s it complicated to do ?"'

column10: b'b" that may have something to do with it. I\'ve never got any of these warnings myself (but have reproduced the problem). I\'ll take another look later."'
b'b" Fixed this in master
column11: at least for me. I\'ve tested with the posted script and it pushes just fine (although it may take a while). Please verify. :)"'

column10: b"b' [Mac OS X] [ListenerIrc] Still Unable to Connect to 204.62.14.135'"
b'b" I have been able to open my IRC port (6667) on my router and can use a IRC client to connect and join with irc://#sparkleshare and also to 204.62.14.135
column11: so I don\'t know why  doesn\'t connect."'

column10: b"b' maybe OSX is blocking only this app?'"
b'b" Good thought
column11: but I don\'t know what might be causing this inside Mac OS X.  I have the Mac OS X firewall turned off and my AV software is currently not on.  However
column12: I took a look at my Netbarrier log and I think I found a clue. When I use an IRC client to 204.62.14.135
column13: the log shows a connection to that URL on port 6667
column14: but when I start  the log shows a different address for port 6667.  I did an IP look up on the address and it is an IP allocated to my DNS service (). I\'m wondering why that is happening.  I\'m going to reset my DNS servers to my ISP\'s default servers and see if that makes a difference."'

column10: b'b\' Okay now this is weird. I reset my router to search my ISP\\\'s default DNS servers (I thought) and it still wouldn\\\'t connect to your IRC server.  The IP was now different.  I downloaded grc\\\'s dns nameserver benchmark and based on that decided to try Level 3 Communication\\\'s servers at 4.2.2.1 and 4.2.2.2.  Voila!!!  Connected without an issue. It seems the server addresses that I assumed were from my ISP were actually my d-link router\\\'s "Advanced DNS" servers.  These servers are similar to OpenDNS as they are filtering addresses
column11: since they have anti-phishing and malware protocols.  This is a good thing for our home since I run my home business off the same ISP that my kids use to access the internet. However
column12: it breaks the SparkleShare app.  I just don\\\'t understand why I can connect to the IRC channel via Chatzilla through the OpenDNS server. This leads me to a follow up question
column13: though.  Is there a tutorial on setting up my own IRC server on my intranet that would service the notifications?  That scenario might be the "best of both worlds" for my home business.  But
column14: I\\\'m going to look more closely at OpenDNS\\\'s options to see if I can "open" up the IRC channel through them. Thanks\''

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: good to hear you found the issue. The VPS SparkleShare uses runs the ratbox-ircd. I didn\'t set it up myself but it shouldn\'t be very hard. We\'re also working on a TCP version of the system that you\'ll be able to run on a server with a simple script. This should land soon."'

column10: b"b' SparkleShare should be dockless on Mac OS'"
b'b\' Hello
column11: I would say that Sparkleshare doesn\\\'t need to have an icon in the dock but just a little icon in the menu bar. After googling a little bit
column12: it appears that setting NSUIElement to 1 in  allows to have this behavior. From url  : "LSUIElement (String Mac OS X) specifies whether the application runs as an agent application. If this key is set to \\xe2\\x80\\x9c1\\xe2\\x80\\x9d
column13: Launch Services runs the application as an agent application. Agent applications do not appear in the Dock or in the Force Quit window. Although they typically run as background applications
column14: they can come to the foreground to present a user interface if desired. A click on a window belonging to an agent application brings that application forward to handle events. The Dock and loginwindow are two applications that run as agent applications." JC\''

column10: b'b" The dock icon is there for various reasons stated here: url Having two processes might be good
column11: but I\'ve no clue how to do it. If someone wants to step up and do it I accepts a patch."'

column10: b'b" Hmm +1. Might try to think up a way to do this
column11: it\'s bugging me as well. Awesome app otherwise!"'

column10: b'b" I would go farther : I would love to have a SparkleShare client without any UI element (not even a menubar item). Once set up
column11: I don\'t need any UI and they\'re taking a lot of screen real estate on my laptop. There are numerous apps that are able[1] to work this way : Alfred
column12: Witch
column13: Screens connect
column14: Growl
column15: Teleport
column16: Keyboard Maestro\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 While most of them use a preferences pane
column17: some simply display configuration window when opening them a second time. Is there already a daemon I could launch with Terminal that would not add any dock or menubar icons ? [1] they display menubar item by default but offer the option of hiding them."'

column10: b'b" @olivierguerriat there are already GUI-less tools that do this (like dvcs-autosync)
column11: so I don\'t see the value in adding this."'

column10: b'b\' I answered by mail but it doesn\\\'t seem to have worked. I wasn\\\'t aware of dvcs-autosync and it could answer my latest question if it worked on Mac OS X

column10: b'b" Sparkleshare doesn\'t handle empty folders"'
b'b\' By the nature of git
column11: empty folders are not versionized. Therefore it\\\'s a task for sparkleshare to force versioning of empty folders since the end user should not deal with the behavior of git
column12: but just using a normal folder as you would do in a normal file system. Therefore
column13: sparkleshare should check whether a folder is empty and add a hidden file
column14: i.e.
column15: to get it versionized by git. This issue applies to two cases:1.  A user creates a new folder (without any file)2.  All files of a folder are deleted For the first case
column16: sparkleshare does nothing because there is no change for git. The second case has a more important impact since a user would not expect a folder to be deleted when he removes all files in it (if he wants to add other files for example). Therefore
column17: sparkleshare need to do two things:If a folder is empty
column18: add a hidden file to itIf a folder is not empty anymore (The second action is not really needed
column19: its just what im thinking about not to confuse the end user ("what is _that_ file suppose to mean?").\''

column10: b'b" This indeed needs to be handled. The custom backend will handle empty folders
column11: but I\'ll have to do a hack for the Git backend until that is ready."'

column10: b"b' Properly handle .git folders'"
b'b" Currently sparkleshare inherits all the  of its backend
column11: Consequently
column12: it does not sync empty dirs (issue 326 url  and it does not sync directories named .git. Furthermore
column13: I expect it to get confused if you have a file named .gitignore
column14: or .gitattributes or to simply ingnore it (haven\'t tried). Conversely
column15: I think that sparkleshare should hide the backend specific characteristics. Particularly
column16: when the backend is git
column17: it should 1) on the way from the client to the server
column18: put a placeholder in empy dirs and remove it on the way from the server to the client2) on the way from the client to the server rename all .git files to .git and remove the  on the way back. Most likely the above issues exist also for the mercurial backend
column19: with sparkleshare being unable to deal with .hg directories (or whatever mercurial has).  In conclusion
column20: any backend should probably be able to specify push and pull rules to hide the peculiarities it brings in: E.g. (for git) On empty directory:PUSH create file placeholder_PULL remove file placeholder_ On  with name matching pattern .git*PUSH rename  to name_PULL rename  named name_ into name"'

column10: b'b\' Argh... the issue tracker has removed parts of my text. on point 2) above you should have read "on the way from the client to the server rename all .git files to .git-random-key and rename to remove the random-key on the way back." Then at the end you should read On  with name matching pattern .git*PUSH rename  to name-randomkeyPULL rename  named name-randomkey into name\''
b"b' see also #223 What I am personally interested in
column11: is the reason why you want sync a git repo itself. It would give you two levels of revision control. Why would you want that?'"

column10: b'b" Obviously
column11: I am not very interested in the 2 levels of revision control
column12: but on the sync. Scenario: I work at 2 different offices in each having a desktop. Furthermore I have one laptop I usually work on and another laptop that I only use at conferences or on vacation
column13: since it is very light but not powerful enough to do anything serious on it. Whatever machine I am on
column14: I want to have all my most recent stuff to work on. I cannot rely on a disk exported via internet
column15: since the laptop can often be disconnected. Using git alone for this does not help. If one day you work on a machine on 5 different projects
column16: you need to remember to push all of them before changing machine. Additionally
column17: if some file in some working tree remains uncommited or unstashed it will not propagate. Currently I use unison. I have an active documents folder that I sync to one of the desktops that is always online and that acts as a central repo. Each project managed by git that is in the active document folder gets synced with both its worktree and the history. Git does not complain for this \'abuse\'. So far so good.  However
column18: everytime I start working on a different machine and (most important) every time I am ready to leave it I need to remember invoking unison. Since every now and then I forget
column19: this can be a pain.  Having an automatic synchronization (a la dropbox or wuala) would probably be an improvement. Unfortunately
column20: sparkleshare cannot (still) be used for the task. Truly
column21: using it would give you two levels of revision control
column22: but that would not be expensive. Provided that you do not repack (too often) in the git repos on the clients
column23: what would end up in the sparkleshare git repo are objects that do not change (a git object can only appear not mutate)
column24: so you really do not waste space. And actually
column25: the double level of revision control can even be useful. In my current scenario (based on unison) if a hard disk breaks down and starts corrupting data
column26: the corrupted data propagates. Unless I can see the problem before all the machines have received the corrupted data
column27: I can experience data loss. With the double level of revision control
column28: I can be safer on this side
column29: particularly if I put the sparkleshare git repo on RAID1. "'

column10: b'b" Work around
column11: use sparkle share to automatically commit / push / pull to your own branch or mirror. Then squash commits / rebase when your changes are complete. Wrapping a whole source control repository in another repository is not ideal. Neither is committing other container formats like zip files
column12: but that\'s a gripe for another time..."'

column10: b"b' Can you please provide better details? What exactly do you mean with work around
column11: use sparkle share to automatically commit / push / pull to your own branch or mirror? Should I set up a different sparkleshare repo for each project I have that is under git? How would I deal with projects that have many different branches so that each branch gets pushed to a corresponding branch on the other side? If there is some workflow that I am currently overlooking
column12: I would be interested in knowing more about it. wrt the rest of the doc: Wrapping a whole source control repository in another repository is not ideal.There was a time when having nested directories was considered not ideal :-)Apart from this
column13: the only thing that looks critical to me (at least with the git backend) is pack files
column14: that might easily get too big for git
column15: but as you mention the issue is not different from what one might encounter with large PDFs
column16: ZIP files (or any format based on that
column17: such as openoffice
column18: docx
column19: jar files)
column20: large  archives
column21: etc.  Note that this includes almost all recent document formats for productivity suites.This is why I advocate that sparkleshare is given the ability to apply transformations on the files on the fly as they are trasfered to and from the server:1) To avoid problems with  that are named in such a way that some specific backend does not like (e.g. .git) or to work around some specific backend peculiarities (e.g. git does not store empty dirs).2) To split too big files in smaller chunks. One option is using a rolling checksum mechanism a la bup
column22: but note that for some file types
column23: recognizing and exploding them (as pristine-tar can do) could be a superior choice.IMHO
column24: all this is quite important for two reasons:1) One wants to hide the peculiarities of the backend. There is an obvious advantage if the user does not need to know if sparkleshare is using a git
column26: unison or sftp backend and does not need to modify  behavior accordingly2) One wants to manage any file and particularly large ones. One of the typical usages of solutions like dropbox or wuala is a-safe-store wrt large documents and photos

column13: recommit) to squash all the automatic commits into a more sanehistory. And manually push this history to the "real" remote. On Fri

column10: b"b' Behavior noticed by dabrahams is IMHO quite understandable.This is exactly what git does when you try adding a dir that includes a .git dir Which brings us back to the initial point.Sparkleshare does not do anything to hide the peculiarities of its backends: If you have the .git backend
column11: you cannot have files named .git\\\\* in what you sync.If say
column12: there was a backend named Foobar using foo and bar files for its own stuff
column13: it would be forbidden to have files named foo and bar in what you sync. IMHO Sparkleshare should conversely do its best to operate seamlessly whatever its backend
column14: without imposing filename rules that the user might not even be aware of.'"

column10: b'b" I can share some of my thoughts. It depends very much what you consider the goal of SparkleShare. It can be just a tool to sync any files. But it can also be seen as a gui around git or another backend. Everything SparkleShare does
column11: would not be too hard to enter manually on the commandline. So if you can\'t run SparkleShare for any reason
column12: you still can simply access the files
column13: and push and update. (although other clients won\'t get a notification). On the other hand
column14: if Sparkleshare needs to rename files before a commit
column15: and rename them back afterwards
column16: things get complicated soon. It would be very awkward to update manually. Also
column17: because it is more complicated
column18: more things can go wrong if you do try it. And from the technical point of view
column19: I don\'t know if it is an good idea to have a git repo inside another git repo. The .git directory contains a kind of database
column20: which is kept consistent with the git executable. I don\'t know any internals of git
column21: but it would be difficult to automatically handle a merge conflict. But of course if you never update simultaneously at two clients
column22: there should not be any problem. Users who use git
column23: will probably understand that. To summarize
column24: I do see advantages of syncing git repo\'s inside a SparkleShare folder
column25: but I am afraid if things get too complicated. At least when you use git as backend."'

b'b" i am not sure i like this suggestion at all i see two options
column11: and i dislike both1. let git (or other back-end) perform the sync to a hidden folder and then have SS sync that local folder to another folder visible to the user. This means that the storage cost for SS will increase.2. let git (or other back-end) perform sync directly to the work folder and then change that folder from under their feet. This will mean losing the ability to work with the backend directly inside the folder (and for me this is one of the strongest points of SS sometimes SS simply can\'t do what git can and sometimes it should not) option 2 can be enhances using  like mechanisms but i see no end to the troubles down that road."'

column10: b'b" This is going to be a huge problem. Git basically looks at the entire history for most of it\'s operations
column11: and doing a repack on a repo with several gigabytes can easily hog all of your cpu und your memory. I crashed servers doing git repack or git gc. Why is the history even stored on the client? Why not just download the latest version? I tried sparkleshare yesterday
column12: i have a 5GB repo full of ~100-200MB files. SparkleShare on Mac hung regularly and after the initial upload the repo had over 10GB even though the files along are just 5. This is unacceptable. I think using git on the client-side is a design-flaw. It would make more sense to use rsync or something to copy the repo and use git on the server to store the history
column13: kind of like DropBox does it with svn (as far as i know). There are options for git to just clone a certain depth
column14: maybe you can look into that. But i\'m pretty sure you\'ll continue to have huge performance problems if you clone everything."'

column13: but then we wouldn\'t have anything usable now. Git does all everything I need to
column14: but it has some downsides. You are free to contribute to the custom backend Rainbows though."'

column10: b'b" @hbons The script removes history beyond a time limit and then tries to garbage collect unreachable objects. Git is very conservative in that respect though. In my experience
column11: git gc doesn\'t (always) clean up recent unreachable files (no matter what you specify as time spec). I\'m not a git-wizard so maybe somebody else could explain what exactly is going on. Normally no conflicts should occur since we have no tags
column12: branches and a linear history. On the history cleaning:The script originates from git-home-history url  I seem to get better results with this sequence of commands after filter-branch: git reset softrm -rf /git reflog expire all expire=now expire-unreachable=0git repack -ad # immediately repackgit gc prune=nowgit push origin +master:master # force pushing the history changes I run this script if I know I removed a lot of files or big files
column13: not as a cron job. I think someone with more knowledge of git should take a look at it first
column14: but I seem to get decent results (well
column15: better than nothing anyways). Full script: url "'

column10: b'b\' The "Operation on non-blocking socket would block"-exception is how the  () method returns. So the  must be called after the exception. To accomplish that I split up in two try-catch-blocks. One for the connect and one in the receiver-loop. At the top of the loop I polled. But the poll always returned with true. Also if the connection was closed.\''
b"b' What if we just do a ping
column11: instead of a poll? url '"

column10: b'b" Doing some work on the \'disconnect\' branch. It seems to work:url  I don\'t think this will cover the sleep case yet
column11: we\'ll have to keep our own timestamps for that as I\'m guessing that ReceiveTimout doesn\'t account for the computer going to sleep."'

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: ping ist connection independent. This would not cover that. It will just recognize a loss of network. Maybe a do-nothing mechanism should be implemented in the fanout
column12: that should be called after each timeout. If the connection was lost this will rise an exception.'"

column10: b"b' Additional to that a platform independent wake-up detection could be implemented. In an extra thread every fixed timeperiod the actual time ist stored and checked with the old one. If the drift is to great the system was in sleep.'"
b'b\' @shilga right that\\\'s what i thought. I\\\'ll add a "ping" signal to the fanout and and implement the sleep detection like you said.\''
b'b" @hbons a shame that I don\'t have time at moment. I would have loved to implement that."'
b'b" Implemented the ping message to fire every 180seconds. If there hasn\'t been a ping for 25% longer we assume the computer sleeped and disconnect (so we can reconnect)."'

b"b' Unclear notification status info text'"

b'b\' Please don\\\'t use "predictive" status texts in menus that\\\'s too confusing. The Sparkleshare client\\\'s menu text for the notification status is such an example: "Turn Notifications Off" ... If a user clicks it he\\\'ll switch the notifications off ok. Nevertheless
column11: often the user only wants to know the current status first before he makes a decision. Please change it to: "Notifications are Off" respective "Notifications are On" If possible with checkbox in front of the entry.\''

column10: b'b" The Apple HIG suggests the pattern currently used
column11: so I\'m going with that."'

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t know Apple\\\'s usecase for this statement
column11: but I go more along with Gnome\\\'s one in Sparkleshare\\\'s case: "Do not use mutable menu items to toggle a two-state setting (for example
column12: Show Toolbar and Hide Toolbar). Present such items as a single check box item instead." _Gnome HIG 3: Chapter 4.3.2.2. Mutable Command Items [1] url  It\\\'s clearer and easier to use IMHO.\''

column10: b'b" I\'ll have a rethink whether we should follow the OS\'s UI guidelines more closely. I tried to have a one size fits all design on Linux and Mac
column11: but with the addition of Windows this may not be the best approach anymore (think button ordering
column12: labels and the menuitem you mentioned)"'

column10: b'b" Thanks for your reply. I had a short review of the MAC OS and Windows guidelines and both are quite unclear what to do in this case. Apple suggest more to implement two different entries with opposite states or a checkbox. Microsoft prefers to put the choices in submenus like:  NotificationsIn general all the big company guidelines aren\'t really clear what to do in this special case. It\'s more about what does the user expect whether he sees an **action** or a **state**?! Currently Sparkleshare sees it as an action. Nevertheless
column11: in the end it changes a state (). If the user expects a state but Sparleshare \'only\' offers an \'action\' the user is confused where to find the current state. So he presses the action and reenters the menu a second time to be sure that the action changed to the opposite. Than he rethinks which state may cause the currently shown _action_.  IMHO the Gnome guideline offers a simple but effective way to solve "'

column10: b'b\' Yes
column11: it\\\'s not that I disagree with you
column12: I just wanted to look at a consistent way of doing this. Having read the three guidelines again
column13: there doesn\\\'t seem to be one
column14: they\\\'re all contradictory. So I\\\'ll follow the individual guidelines as much as possible. "[X] Show Notifications" for GNOME and Windows
column15: and "Turn Notifications " on Mac. The problem with Windows is though that I need to somehow put the regular checkbox in the menu
column16: because the IsChecked option displays a weird kind of checkmark
column17: which doesn\\\'t have a visible unchecked state (it looks even more confusing).\''

column10: b'b" I think it\'s just a bit tricky with these **** items within menus.  You are right
column11: it may be the best way to follow the guidelines individually. However it might be possible that you use the \'_checkmark solution_\' for all the OSs. The last sentence in the [Toggled Menu Items]url  section seams to be more a warning than an advice.**Don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t use a checkmark when the toggled item indicates the presence or absence of a feature** In such a case
column12: users can\\xe2\\x80\\x99t be sure whether the checkmark means that the feature is currently in effect or that choosing the command turns the feature on.* That\'s exactly the problem when checkmarks (states) are used together with an \'action phrase\'. I guess
column13: they mean
column14: if you want to use a checkmark then it might be good just to use it together with one subject like in **[x] Notifications** instead of **[x] Show Notifications** because the latter mixes up the current _state_ with an _action_. Presumably they want to push the designer more in the direction of their previous paragraph:**Use a checkmark when the toggled items represents an attribute that is currently in effect.** It\\xe2\\x80\\x99s easy for users to scan for checkmarks in a list of attributes to find the ones that are in effect. For example
column15: in the Mail Format menu
column16: users can see at a glance which styles have been applied to the selected text. IMHO if you reduce it to **[x] Notifications** in all three OSs that should be ok. I probably would summarize it as: \'_Never use verbs (actions) together with checkmarked items (states)_\'."'

column10: b'b\' "[X] Notifications" could work. I don\\\'t see it working where the unchecked state mark isn\\\'t visible like on the Mac. (on Windows too
column11: but I can work around that). GNOME actually recommends your proposal: url \''

column10: b'b\' I just saw "[ ] Notifications" on windows and was confused because without a visible "this is a not-checked checkbox" symbol it looks like any other menu entry
column11: ie "Click here to display a new window which lists your notifications" >_<\''

column10: b'b" @shish this is a bug that really should be reported on Windows I think
column11: but I\'m working on getting the normal checkbox in the menu there and it\'s tricky."'

column10: b'b\' So the hack i\\\'m planning is to get the checkbox control as an image and put it in the menu item. This works fine
column11: however for some reason I\\\'m not able to get the "checked" image. Any help would be welcome here.\''

column10: b"b' After wasting hours and hours on trying to get the checkbox images
column11: it turns out you can use checkboxes as an icon... Anyway
column12: this is fixed now.'"

column10: b'b\' Well I know the issue now causing the repositories to go broken. Set-up is like this: .gitignore contains: These combined cause GIT to ignore the symlink. However possibly SparkleShare does not. Edit: And I accidentally hit close issue >_Edit 2: Elaboration
column11: with "Sparkleshare not ignoring" I mean when renaming the HEAD file in .git folders found in \''

column10: b'b" The following is happening: Before a commit
column11: SparkleShare traverses the tree the prepare for a commit
column12: without taking the gitignore into account.It finds ~/
column13: and thinks it\'s an added git repo
column14: so renames  there to prevent any problems. This is because it doesn\'t match ~/
column15: and so it doesn\'t realise it\'s actually a SparkleShare repo. I can fix by adding an extra check for the .sparkleshare file."'

column10: b'b" Wouldn\'t the solution be honoring the .gitignore so not traversing into folders that are added to the .gitignore?"'
b'b" No
column11: because the problem would still occur if the symlink wasn\'t in the gitignore."'

column10: b"b' But what about folders that are in the gitignore that contain .git folders? Or is that too edge-case?'"
b'b" @xeross those will also be renamed. The gitignore isn\'t a feature of SparkleShare but a (sometimes useful) side effect of using git
column11: so I treat it as an edge case."'

b'b\' I\\\'m sorry to post on a close ticket but I think this might help someone. I made several tests on a W7 64 bit in "good shape". Running version 0.9.0 installed from .msi I was experiencing the error reported in this page and in several other tickets (ex.: ref #716 ref #629): crash when adding a new project
column11: crash when updating from the server after a huge push: it was systematic. Then I updated the system at 2012-07-04 but nothing changed. I wondered if the MS indexing service would cause any issue so I disabled the indexing and  the search service for the SparkleShare  folder and the Volume Shadow service for all the system. Immediately the application became much more stable and allowed me to successfully import 3 huge project (some thousands file
column12: several hundreds MB) Here the guides I followed:url url url  I confirm that removing the ~/ folder after a crash is a good practice when the application is stuck and crashes when adding a project.\''

column11: the windows version crash all time.  I think the problem can be found in  . The method HasRemoteChanges calls  CurrentRevision which can give back a null. In HasRemoteChanges the make if (!remote_(current_revision))  {...} which crash sparkleshare.  One solution could be to return  in CurrentRevision.  RegardsApollo'"

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t see how it could return null... "git rev-parse HEAD" will always return something if the repo was added by SparkleShare? Did you do something to the repo? Also
column11: which version?\''

column10: b"b' Version: Current git master. The method CurrentRevision checks if (  == 0) {...}  else return null. In my case  is sometimes 128 which means CurrentRevision return null.  In method HasRemoteChanges the string current_revision = CurrentRevision; is null in case of a Error.  Then in line 167 the code try to parse the string which will be crash.  Hopefully it is more clear. '"

column10: b'b\' Do you have any files with invalid characters? From MSDN: Path members do
column11: however
column12: validate the contents of a specified path string
column13: and throw an ArgumentException exception if the string contains characters that are not valid in path strings
column14: as defined in the characters returned from the GetInvalidPathChars method. For example
column15: on Windows-based desktop platforms
column16: invalid path characters might include quote (")
column17: less than ()
column18: pipe (|)
column19: backspace (\\\\b)
column21: and Unicode characters 16 through 18 and 20 through 25.\''

column10: b"b' SparkleShare takes forever to update'"

b"b' I just copied a directory with 21MB of files.Approximately 30 files in 3 directories one of them having 7Mb the rest just a few kilo.It is spinning around for about an hour now and 0% progress shown.Windows version. '"
b"b' The issue seems to occur when there are to many sub-directories and in to many I am not talking about 20 but 5.'"
b"b' This issue has been fixed already for the next release.'"
b"b' When is the next release coming?'"
b"b' Cutom path issues'"
b'b\' Right now
column11: custom paths in Sparkleshare is fairly non-ideal and does not match the ease of the rest of the experience. Setting custom project paths requires adding the to the config file.  Getting this right the first time was a frustrating experience of trial and error
column12: not knowing what the correct path format was
column13: starting and stopping sparkleshare
column14: copying and deleting files etc. Setting the default sparkleshare parent folder seemingly requires  but I have never gotten this to work. Additionally
column15: the wiki info is very sparse
column16: and their seems to be conflicting info in the issues section.  Changing paths is really critical for many people. It seems fairly high priority toa) Edit the wiki page about changing paths so that it shows how to change the path of the Parent sparkleshare folder
column17: as well as custom paths per project.  Also clarifying proper path formats would really help a lot of people I believe
column18: given that it varies across systems
column19: especially windows.  Also
column20: the names of the example projects are kind of confusing given the context.  Additionally
column21: note if there are any old configuration options that no longer exist as a proper setting or how the different versions of sparkle share differed?  I get the impression that some of these configuration options are no longer even available?  b) If possible
column22: Have a GUI setting for the default Sparkleshare parent folder path.  Also
column23: having an optional setting to set a custom path for the new project would be very helpful
column24: and save time when creating sparkleshare projects in custom locations. Additionally
column26: it seems like sparkle share completely forgets about its existence.  Maybe have sparkle share ask "Did you  your project?  Would you like to enter its new path or just forget about it?"\''

It seems like both custom Sparkleshare parent folders for default locations of new projects as well as custom project folders are important.  Is is possible to have both have both and as viable options? Additionally

column16: really great program!  I love the concept."'

b"b' Issues deploying using dazzle script.'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: this seems like a great project
column12: but it isn\\\'t very easy to deploy
column13: even with the dazzle script. Here are some of the problems using it on a raspberry pi:1. The script clearly needs root access
column14: but it doesn\\\'t say anything about that on your page or when you run the script. You at least need to add "sudo"s around everywhere. 2. There\\\'s this syntax error:  pi@raspberrypi ~ $ dazzle setup (1/4) Creating account "storage"... /: line 25: [: =: unary operator expected  useradd: Permission denied. useradd: cannot lock /; try again later.3. It doesn\\\'t detect errors at all
column15: and will happily breeze through permission denied\\\'s and tell you (erroneously) that everything is ok. E.g. you have to look quite hard for the error below I certainly didn\\\'t notice it!  pi@raspberrypi ~ $ dazzle link Paste the contents of "~/ Name\\\'s link " (found on the client) into the field below and press .  Link code: ssh-rsa   AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAlgh;wodfguhn;oihoehrkrtjh9ehgjhdkfjghGbrPinEQIIsgk3FSb5B8plEHjBrfAe96Kv5+PZcj+cfbo4QGe3p0uhRh++Im7qmBvb24+wZQfC8DsqBCIQQrhbbMElKoCS2T7xPybptsYTRn8zHHrlbIO2xjhHV89qr1yqOUC83PaNAhXlq5aM+Yft8ZEsyaDeuV+q9tvEBjOJsYtVQ0plFWxAb4RQ== Lappy /: line 137: /: Permission denied  The client with this link code can now access projects.  <Totally untrue! Repeat this step to link more clients.4. You\\\'re distributing a shell script! I mean they\\\'re fine for one-off things
column16: but distributing them to others is pretty much a terrible idea and will _always_ result in stupid errors
column17: like not working in paths with spaces
column18: and [ expecting a unary operator. I really really recommend you use a python script instead! I had a look at dazzle and it wasn\\\'t too long so I made a python version for you to use instead. See below.5. The script creates a user with no password
column19: which apparently makes it "locked" and prevents ssh from letting you log in
column20: even with public key authentication. I added a password to the "storage" user and then it worked. Ok here is the script. I tested it a bit but not extensively. It _should_ work with project names with spaces
column21: assuming git is also ok with that
column22: which I somewhat doubt. I haven\\\'t fixed the issue with locked accounts and there are some other TODOs.  \''

column10: b'b\' hi! thanks taking the time to point out these issues. it would be great to have an easy setup on the Raspberry Pi.i went ahead and integrated some of your improvements into the Dazzle script. i don\\\'t see a huge benefit of switching over to python however. i\\\'ve chosen to use a bash script to keep things simple and readable
column11: and to make it easy for sysadmins to see what\\\'s going on with their server. another reason was that the initial setup tutorial was simply a straightforward steps of commands. now to address your issues raised: 1 and 3: these seems to be the same issue: not running as root screws things up. i\\\'ve added a check for the root user in the script now. Debian doesn\\\'t come with sudo enabled by default
column12: so we can\\\'t use that. the script assumes a default install of either Debian or Red . you say that the requirement of running as root isn\\\'t documented anywhere. this isn\\\'t true
column13: it\\\'s mentioned both on the home page as in the source repo. this is probably because most of us scan instead of reading every line
column14: so the suggestion to add a root check to the script is definitely a good one. 2: "/: line 25: [: =: unary operator expected" i\\\'m not sure why this happens. it doesn\\\'t happen for me on Debian 6. i\\\'ll have to investigate a bit more to fix this but it doesn\\\'t seem like a big problem. 4: "" i disagree here. rewriting it will cause other errors
column15: and as you mention it isn\\\'t complete
column16: so we\\\'ll have to work on it more. it\\\'s not that Dazzle uses any obscure commands or arguments. these commands are quite stable and in any common Linux distro. the python script also calls out to different commands
column17: which will have the same potential problems as a bash script has. 5: "The script creates a user with no password
column18: which apparently makes it "locked"" i haven\\\'t seen this problem before. i also don\\\'t know what kind of distro your Raspberry Pi uses
column19: but i want to make this work
column20: so we can look into this.\''

column10: b'b" here are the changes i\'ve made: url "'
b'b\' No problem
column11: sorry if I seemed strident by the way! Let\\\'s face it
column12: nobody is totally happy to submit bug reports! After using the mac client for a big
column13: it seems really good
column14: so I am quite keen to make this project as easy to use as possible. 1/3. Yeah I guess I could be accused of skimming! (Unless you only just added the "run the following commands as root" instructions.) But I\\\'m a firm believer in the principle that software shouldn\\\'t really require instructions (as much as possible)
column15: so at least checking for root is a requirement. Glad you\\\'ve added it! 2. I know what causes this bug and how to fix it
column16: but I\\\'m not actually going to tell you because I want you to _strongly_ reconsider your choice of bash
column17: and I want you to experience the joy of bugs caused by bash being a big hack. You\\\'re right about it being extra work to finish the python. But it will only take me half an hour or so
column18: and I am willing to do it if you promise you\\\'ll use the script instead. Here are my thoughts on why it is such a bad idea to use bash.1. Your script isn\\\'t designed to be read. I agree that in some cases
column19: like when you are explaining how to do a sysadmin task
column20: people are going to read the script to understand it
column21: and then probably run the commands themselves. In that case a bash script is simple and good. But when you have something with functions
column22: that 99% of users aren\\\'t going to read. In that case it should be robust rather than simple. If this isn\\\'t your intention you should get rid of all the "dazzle setup" type commands and just list the "adduser storage" type stuff on the home page. I don\\\'t think that\\\'s a good idea though.2. Bash can\\\'t handle paths containing spaces. A well-known and well-ignored problem. Sure you _can_ just about manage it
column23: with an array of multilayered quoting methods
column24: but you WILL get it wrong at some point. Bash just is fundamentally incompatible with spaces because it uses them to separate items in lists.3. In python it is true that I had to call () more than I would like! But it has two HUGE advantages over bash: first
column26: since the arguments are given in a true non-space-delimited list
column28: it throws an error if the command fails
column29: rather than blindly continuing. Again you _can_ do this in bash
column30: but it isn\\\'t pretty and nobody really does it.4. Bash in general is very error prone and generally crazy. Have you _seen_ how [ is implemented? I will check into the locked user issue a bit more if you like. And let me know if you want to use my (finished!) !\''

column10: b'b\' most languages suck in some way. i think we\\\'ll be just fine keeping things as they are currently. we\\\'ve covered and fixed most of the issues in this report now
column11: except for the broken user account. i\\\'ve added an explicit "PubkeyAuth yes" line to the sshd_config to make sure that that is at least enabled. not sure if it fixes the issue though. i\\\'m thinking it may be an older openssh version you\\\'re using (you haven\\\'t told me what distro you\\\'re using on your Pi).\''

column10: b'b\' True but it doesn\\\'t follow that because there are no perfect languages
column11: all languages are equal! Bash is not a robust language
column12: no matter how you look at it. It is a shame that you are sticking with a sub-par solution. Do you check if a PubkeyAuth setting already exists? It would be a silly bug to add it again
column13: and sshd may freak out in that case. I found the reason why it isn\\\'t working so you should probably remove this addition
column14: and just search for "PubkeyAuth no" instead and print a warning
column15: since it is enabled by default. The reason is: useradd by default uses ! in the password field in /
column16: which means the account is locked
column17: but you can do useradd .... password \\\\* which sets it to *
column18: and then the account isn\\\'t locked
column19: but there is still no valid password. I couldn\\\'t really find this documented properly anywhere but it seems to be how it works. Remember to think about how inappropriate bash is for this kind of thing when you are adding that *! /broken record.\''

column10: b"b' so what was the issue?'"
b'b\' Hello together
column11: to add something to the discussion... I had the problem that on Win7 64-bit the process to add a new hosted project just hang in the first step. The .tmp-folder did not "grow" or something
column12: so I suggested a problem before actually getting on the server. Trying to connect via ssh resulted in being asked for my password
column13: so I believed there had not been a key transfer yet. When adding the project via the SparkleShare GUI I hoped that I would perhaps be asked for a user password
column14: but in the forums and wiki here I found hints how this worked on Unix-based systems. So I tried the following with the original installation of SparkleShare.Open a terminal on your windows client and navigate to C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\SparkleShare\\\\msysgit\\\\bin  cd "C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\SparkleShare\\\\msysgit\\\\bin"Generate a new keypair with name id_rsa and now password  ssh-keygen -t rsa  answer the question for the name of the keypair with "id_rsa" and set no password for the key  The key and public key will be saved in "C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\SparkleShare\\\\msysgit\\\\bin"Copy the public key via SCP to your server and save it here:  "~/"  I used WinSCP for this
column15: because the shell command in msysgit\\\\bin did not work
column16: perhaps just wrong syntaxLog in via SSH on your Server and copy the public key to the authorized_keys:  cat id_ >  Logout and do the following on your windows clientNavigate to "C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\SparkleShare\\\\" and copy your private key there  cd C:\\\\Program Files (x86)\\\\SparkleShare\\\\  copy ..\\\\bin\\\\id_rsa . After that I could login to the server without using my password
column17: so I suggested this would be enough. But because SparkleShare generated a keypair named by a timestamp in the folder "%appdata%\\\\sparkleshare" on my windows client I suggested it uses this pair for authenticating and this did not work. So I moved the files to a backup folder
column18: copied my id_ and id_rsa to this destination and restarted SparkleShare. This worked!Perhaps someone can try this
column19: too. I hope my post helped some of you. Regards
column20: Oliver\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'ve the code running. It is setting the HTTP(S)_PROXY environment variable and it\\\'s configuring git via "git config" for the proxy. It picks up the configured proxy nicely. (Implemented as separate method "SetupProxyEnvironment" and called in SparkleFetcher in  It\\\'s in my repository) My problem still is to get around the ssh-keygen. I found solutions on the web via PROXY_COMMAND="nc ... <netcat options" in the ssh config. However I would really like to avoid a dependency to netcat. \''
b'b" I\'ve hit a roadblock. Proxycommand is now implemented and it works for ssh. However
column11: ssh-keyscan is still a problem. It does not share any code with ssh and does not read the ssh config and so it does also ignore the proxycommand inside. url "'

column10: b"b' IIRC
column11: my solution for supporting proxying for .onion addresses was to justdisable ssh-keyscan.  As far as I understand it
column12: it is a useful optimization
column13: but it is not required.'"

column10: b'b\' @eighthave: Thank you for the suggestion. I have skipped the ssh-keyscan for my URL at the moment. What ssh-keyscan in the end does is avoiding that the user needs to type in "yes" to explicitly accept the ssh public key. I think the same could be done by calling ssh with the parameter-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no. After this
column11: SparkleShare seems to work fine via proxy. EDIT: I\\\'m skipping ssh-keyscan for proxy connections now and I\\\'ve added StrictHostKeyChecking no to the users  file. The code is in my repository feel free to try it. However a second pitfall is
column12: that a lot of proxies do not allow access to port 22. CAUTION: Currently the $ is completely erased and written again. I think about moving it to a more private place later on... ![sparkleshare_proxy]url \''

column10: b"b' Password of encrypted projects is stored in plain text'"

b'b\' During first access to a encrypted project (containing "-crypto" in its name) the user has to choose a password. This password is stored in plain text in the file $.1. The password should be at least pseudo-encrypted.2. Way more important: There should be an option to ask the user for the password every time SparkleShare is started. After that
column11: the password should be kept in memory only (in encrypted form).  2b. Also
column12: there are techniques to make it harder to extract the password (see the program KeePass for example
column13: it\\\'s also written in C#; didn\\\'t examined it myself
column14: just read about it).\''

column10: b'b" this is a noble goal
column11: but it probably won\'t help make things more secure
column12: mostly because of technical reasons: the openssl command is used to encrypt the files. it is run as a git filter just before things move  of the database. unfortunately
column13: the command requires the password to be passed as plain text as an argument or as a file
column14: this exposes the password to the OS. this also limits the use of keyrings: we could store the password there
column15: but it will be exposed to the OS at some point anyway when we try to pass it to the command. we would have the same problem trying to scramble the password somehow
column16: and as SparkleShare is open source
column17: this algorithm can quickly be figured out. more importantly there\'s the fact that the files are already unencrypted on your local disk. if someone manages to get access to your system the battle is already lost. password or no password."'

column10: b'b" btw
column11: please let me know if someone does know how to do this properly and i\'ve missed something."'

column10: b'b" You are right that the fight for the shared files is already lost. But the password itself is a very precious information in many cases (many
column11: many users don\'t remember countless different passwords and therefore use the same password on various occasions and services). If you rly do not want to address this problem
column12: please at least add a hint in the password dialog that tells the user to avoid choosing a password they are using in any other situation. It is true that the OS has to get the password at some point. But atm the password is stored _inside_ the SparkleShare folder with no protection whatsoever. Every malware or person with physical access can grab it without any effort. If more ppl get knowledge of SparkleShare and the masses begin to use it (and i rly hope they do
column13: the clean and slim design with usage of common components like SSH and git is just awesome)
column14: this _will_ become a serious problem. The malware writers just ignore it atm because SparkleShare has not the critical mass of users yet. In my opinion it is way more difficult to steal the password when it is never stored in the file system. IIRC it is possible to hand over the password to openssl by stdin
column15: which is much harder to hack than reading a plain text file in the file system."'

column10: b'b" i didn\'t know about the option to pass the password via stdin. that\'s something to investigate."'
b'b" it seems that this isn\'t a possibility either. git already passes the file to encrypt through stdin...i\'ve updated the text when asking for a password
column11: that\'s the least i could do."'

column10: b"b' Changeable password for client side encryption'"
b'b\' Actually passwords used for encrypt files can\\\'t  be changed.  Why you don\\\'t create a big-giant-random-password (P1)
column11: encrypt the files with P1
column12: and encrypt the P1 with "user password (P2)"?If the user would like to change the password
column13: he changes password P2; allowing users to change encryption password. Considering that password P1 is bigger than a normal password choosed by user
column14: the encrypted files are more secure against brute-force attacks. P.S.: sorry about my bad english\''

column10: b'b" that\'s a cool idea!"'

b'b" An even cooler idea would be to implement a simple architecture that enables client-side encryption & usable share features at the same time. Each project\'s files are encrypted with a big giant random password (P1). P1 is encrypted with a password chosen by user A
column11: owner of the project (P2A). If A wants to share the project files with user B
column12: the sparkleshare client decrypts P1 with P2A
column13: re-encrypts with B\'s public key (sent by B when accepting invitation)
column14: and then store it somewhere on GIT server. In turn
column15: B\'s client downloads the encrypted P1 from the server
column16: decrypts it with B\'s private  key
column17: and then asks B to set  own password (P2B) to reencrypt P1. In this way
column18: each user may have a different encryption password  (P2X) while sharing the same encryption key (P1).What do you think?"'

column10: b'b" @alpianon wasn\'t that what @jonathann was saying? :)"'
b"b' I think It is the same idea
column11: but applied in another functionality (sharing encrypted folders).'"

column10: b"b' yesss!It is an implementation of the idea
column11: which however would need that sparkleshare client direclty handles invitations. @hbons do you think that in theory it would be possible?'"

column10: b"b' @alpianon It needs to be made very clear to users that in this case sharing involves the entire repository.  I can just imagine the scenario where users think they are sharing one file or folder
column11: but are in fact sharing the entire key.This suggestion also requires the establishment of some sort of public key infrastructure so that you can confirm you have the correct public key for the person you want to share with. @jonathann Its a good idea.  It follows the same pattern that something like Truecrypt or Keepass uses to store the encryption key.'"

column10: b'b" You could solve the public key infrastructure problem by using PGP. However if you use such an asymmetric key encryption it would mean there would have to be a separate copy of the repository for each user sharing it (encrypted with their public key). Since the git server can\'t manage the synchronization between the different encrypted versions this would have to be done client-side too
column11: meaning every time you change something in your sparkleshare folder it has to be encrypted with each user\'s public key and sent to all the repositories for the different users. In this case it\'s perhaps better to share the symmetric password with your collaborators (sending it to them encrypted with PGP). You can use a very long symmetric password if you want to. Changing the (symmetric) password shouldn\'t be that difficult
column12: right? The client just has to use the new password to encrypt the data and send it to the repository. Everybody else would then have to change the password on their repository too
column13: or they can\'t access the new commits. Old passwords should be kept so old commits can still be accessed
column14: or they would need to be re-encrypted."'

column14: please do!"'

b"b' Conflicts on empty files in encrypted projects'"
b'b\' I have recurring problems with conflicts. The problem seems similar to #87 and #721
column11: although no case change was involved. I\\\'m using SparkleShare 1.0 with encryption with two users. Both are in Windows. One user creates a new empty text file in the shared folder and immediately renames it (to a completely different name). This causes the original file creation and the rename to be recorded in history.  The other user then gets a notification that there was a conflict and supposedly copies of all conflicting files were created. When the second user looks into his shared folder
column12: only the original file (with the name when it was first created) is located there. No copies.  After that
column13: user 2 gets no more updates from the repository and a new "conflict happened" warning pops up every few seconds. I\\\'m suspecting this has something to do with the files being empty. This is a part of my log from when the problem happened:  You can see that SparkleShare assumed that conflicts had been resolved multiple times. During that time
column14: no files were changed
column15: so all the conflicts seem to stem from the same rename at the beginning.\''

column10: b'b" that commit will prevent long strings from being passed through dbus. is really doubt this is the issue
column11: but can you give that a try? the only other possible cause i can think of is the user icon being passed too. they\'re really small however. can you check the files sizes of the images in ~/?"'

column10: b'b" I\'ll have to spin up packages with this commit
column11: and distribute to the affected users. This won\'t be until next week."'

column10: b'b" I reproduced this crash once and I verified that \'title\' and \'subtext\' are proper strings not long at all. Also we don\'t have avatars. I doubt it really reads a 500Mb message over dbus. I\'m pretty sure it is dbus-sharp not interpreting correctly the message header
column11: or some wrongly formatted msg being sent. As far as I can tell the only user of dbus-sharp in SparkleShare is notification system. Since I\'ve seen effort to port to GIR bindings
column12: maybe we could just use libnotify glib introspection instead of notify-sharp ? Would that be an acceptable solution? Are dbus-sharp and notify-sharp maintained nowadays anyway?"'

column10: b'b" @xclaesse i\'m open to any solution for this problem
column11: but i\'m not too familiiar with the alternatives. currently
column12: just notify-sharp is used
column13: but i think we could use dbus sharp to send raw messages to (if i recall correctly)  or something? you are right that the only use of dbus is the notification system through notify-sharp.i\'ll accept any patch that can fix this issue and supports the same features
column14: even if it means using a different library or calling out to the notify-send command. i don\'t think notify-sharp has had a release in years."'

column10: b'b" closing this as it seems to be in issue either in notify-sharp or dbus-sharp. i would forward this bug
column11: but i don\'t exactly know where..."'

column10: b'b" ok
column11: i can\'t believe how silly a bug this was. the notification related methods weren\'t being called on the main thread
column12: causing all kinds of issues! @meebey and @knocte figured this out. this is pretty certainly the cause of this crash."'

column10: b'b" Doing Dbus calls from the non-GUI thread can cause a lot of issues
column11: but it doesn\'t have to be this particular one. Jo should confirm if this fixes the issue for him as he seems to be able to reproduce it."'

column10: b'b" here\'s a possible fix. @directhex can you deploy that and see if that solves the problem?"'
b'b" let me know if you\'ve had any luck with this. closing this meanwhile. :)"'
b'b" @directhex ping? it\'s not very fair that you publish a bounty
column11: and when a possible fix is implemented
column12: no answer is given ;-)"'

But even simpler I just linked my against (I never let custom compiled stuff enter  ). Problem solved. Thanks for this project. Like it. b'b" I totally get what you are trying to do. I wrote a software product nearly twenty years ago that did this sort of thing (but only for windows). It\'s focus was on being a self-healing software distribution channel over low-bandwidth connections. The idea was that if the software was somehow compromised on a client
column11: or that is was updated on the host then deltas of the changes would be deployed to keep everyone up to date. Git wasn\'t around then and it provides a good way to do the background work. I haven\'t worked through your project work yet
